{{advert|date=June 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = GuideStar | image = [[File:GuideStar USA logo.jpg]] | type = Non-profit Organization | founded_date = 1994 (as Philanthropic Research, Inc.) | tax_id = 54-1774039 | registration_id = | founder = Arthur "Buzz" Schmidt | location = [[Williamsburg, Virginia]], [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Oakland, California]] | coordinates = | origins = Williamsburg, Virginia, U.S. | key_people = Jacob Harold, Evan Paul, James Dobrzeniecki, Debra Snider, Mizmun Kusairi, Adrian Bordone | area_served = United States | product = Nonprofit Analysis Solutions | mission = To revolutionize philanthropy by providing information that advances transparency, enables users to make better decisions, and encourages charitable giving.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.guidestar.org/rxg/about-us/index.aspx |title= GuideStar |publisher= guidestar.org |date= |accessdate= May 14, 2015}}</ref> | focus = Nonprofit Information | method = | revenue = 10,676,538 | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 83 | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = Better data. Better decisions. Better world. | former name = Philanthropic Research, Inc. | homepage = {{url |https://www.guidestar.org/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''GuideStar USA, Inc.''' is an information service specializing in reporting on U.S. [[nonprofit]] companies. <ref name="VirginianPilot2010">[http://hamptonroads.com/2010/10/williamsburgs-guidestar-pushes-quiet-revolution Walzer, Philip (2010). "Williamsburg's GuideStar pushes quiet revolution", ''The Virginian-Pilot'', 21 October 2010]</ref> In 2016, its database provided information on 2.5 million organizations.<ref>Wyland, Michael. "GuideStar Introduces Program Metrics Section for Nonprofit Profiles." Non Profit News For Nonprofit Organizations | Nonprofit Quarterly. N.p., May 11, 2016. Web. April 3, 2017.</ref>
GuideStar was one of the first central sources of information on U.S. nonprofits<ref>{{cite|title=Gates Foundation Pledges $3-Million to GuideStar to Enhance Nonprofit Database|publisher=The Chronicle of Philanthropy|date=November 10, 2014}}</ref> and is the world's largest source of information about nonprofit organizations.<ref>"Rock and Roll Tendencies Will Perform Feb. 12." Canon City Daily Record. N.p., January 26, 2017. Web. April 3, 2017. http://www.canoncitydailyrecord.com/news/penrose/ci_30753340/whats-happening</ref> GuideStar was founded in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]] in September 1994 and received tax-exempt status in 1996,<ref>[http://www2.guidestar.org/rxg/about-us/history.aspx GuideStar History]</ref> the same year the company began posting nonprofit organizations' financial reports to the World Wide Web.<ref name="TimeMagazine">[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,181602,00.html Rawe, Julie (2001). "Where Does Your Gift Go?", ''Time Magazine'', 28 October 2001]</ref>
GuideStar also serves to verify that a recipient organization is established and that donated funds go where the donor intended for individuals looking to give in the wake of disasters.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hays|first=Julie|title=How to help after the superstorm|url=http://us.cnn.com/2012/10/30/us/iyw-how-to-help-after-sandy/index.html?iref=24hours|work=Impact Your World|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 8, 2012}}</ref>
In 2013, GuideStar announced major changes to its GuideStar Exchange program, which allows nonprofits to supplement the public information that is available from the IRS.<ref>Cunniffe, Eileen. "GuideStar to Collect Nonprofit Governance Information in League with BoardSource." Non Profit News For Nonprofit Organizations | Nonprofit Quarterly. N.p., April 16, 2015. Web. April 3, 2017.</ref> GuideStar Nonprofit Profiles implemented three seals based on the information a nonprofit provides in its profile: Bronze, Silver, and Gold.<ref>Cunniffe, Eileen. "GuideStar to Collect Nonprofit Governance Information in League with BoardSource." Non Profit News For Nonprofit Organizations | Nonprofit Quarterly. N.p., April 16, 2015. Web. April 3, 2017.</ref> In 2016, a new seal that allowed nonprofits to share progress and results for their mission, GuideStar Platinum, was introduced.<ref>Wyland, Michael. "GuideStar Introduces Program Metrics Section for Nonprofit Profiles." Non Profit News For Nonprofit Organizations | Nonprofit Quarterly. N.p., May 11, 2016. Web. April 3, 2017.</ref>
==History== *'''1994:''' Arthur "Buzz" Schmidt founded Philanthropic Research, Inc. in Williamsburg, Virginia as a company dedicated to helping donors make better giving decisions by providing easily accessibly nonprofit information.<ref>{{cite news|last=Taylor|first=April|title=COLLECTION OF DATA CALLED A BLESSING FOR CHARITIES|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/dailypress/access/709688081.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+8%2C+2004&author=APRIL+TAYLOR+Daily+Press&pub=Daily+Press&edition=&startpage=B.10&desc|work=Daily Press|date=October 8, 2004}}</ref> *'''1996:''' Philanthropic Research, Inc. officially received [[Tax-exempt status|tax-exempt]] status as a [[501(c)]](3) public charity, and in July, published the GuideStar Directory of American Charities, a CD and printed index that presented full reports on 35,000 charities and partial reports on 7,000 other charities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayfield|first=Dave|title=ONLINE INFORMATION ON CHARITIES "THERE'S HUGE CHARITABLE CAPACITY THAT'S UNTAPPED. WE JUST NEED TO INCREASE THE CONFIDENCE OF DONORS TO GIVE|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-73138076.html|work=The Virginian-Pilot|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}</ref> That fall, Philanthropic Research, Inc. officially launched its GuideStar website, allowing it to update the data more frequently and provide more extensive information.<ref>{{cite web|last=Akst|first=Daniel|title=GuideStar: Data About Nonprofits Goes Online|url=http://carnegie.org/fileadmin/Media/Publications/GuideStar_Data_About_Nonprofits_Goes_Online.pdf|work=Carnegie Results|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}</ref> The organizations began doing business under the name, "GuideStar," although its official name remained Philanthropic Research, Inc. until September 2008.<ref>https://learn.guidestar.org/about-us/history</ref> *'''1997:''' GuideStar began posting information on all 501(c)(3) nonprofits in the IRS Business Master File. By December, the database held information on more than 600,000 nonprofits.<ref>{{cite web|last=Associated Press|title=Warning: Be smart with charitable donations|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YIAfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZX0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6959,1379617&dq=guidestar+public+charity&hl=en{{!}}work|work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|accessdate=June 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Waldman|first=Amy|title=In a World of Good Causes, Beware Waste and a Few Crooks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/09/giving/in-a-world-of-good-causes-beware-waste-and-a-few-crooks.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 15, 2011|date=December 9, 1997}}</ref> *'''1998:''' GuideStar provided digitized 990 data on its website's individual public charities pages.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Fletcher|title=In the 990's Fine Print, the Innards of Nonprofits|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/18/giving/in-the-990-s-fine-print-the-innards-of-nonprofits.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 30, 2011|date=November 18, 1998}}</ref> *'''1999:''' In October, GuideStar began posting 501(c)(3) public charities' annual information returns, known as IRS Forms 990 and 990-EZ.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cay Johnston|first=David|title=ACCOUNTABILITY; For Checking Out a Charity, Remember the Number 990|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/11/20/giving/accountability-for-checking-out-a-charity-remember-the-number-990.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=June 30, 2011|date=November 20, 2000}}</ref> *'''2001:''' GuideStar began publishing an annual Nonprofit Compensation Report.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lipman|first=Harvy|title=Unbalanced Pay Scales|url=http://philanthropy.com/article/Unbalanced-Pay-Scales/54350/|work=The Chronicle of Philanthropy|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref> The first edition was derived from compensation data reported to the IRS by nearly 75,000 charities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wooster|first=Martin Morse|title=Paying Charity CEOs|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72611064.html|work=American Enterprise|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref> In response to 9/11, GuideStar expanded the database to include non-charitable organizations eligible to accept tax-deductible contributions, along with special 9/11 funds and programs.<ref>{{cite news|last=Editors|title=Internet scams are exploiting the generosity of Americans helping the victims of the terrorist attacks|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ST&s_site=dfw&p_multi=ST&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EEAAA70A8B609A4&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=Fort Worth Star-Telegram|accessdate=July 27, 2011|date=September 20, 2001}}</ref> GuideStar also collaborated with the New York State Attorney General’s Office, providing data for the WTC Relief Info site.<ref>{{cite news|last=Editors|title=IRS CLEARS CREATION OF CHARITIES, LITTLE OVERSIGHT, NO FOLLOW-UP SINCE SEPT. 11 ATTACKS|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CL&s_site=ledgerenquirer&p_multi=CL&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F1D2639289F5728&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=Columbus Ledger-Enquirer|accessdate=July 27, 2011|date=February 18, 2002}}</ref> *'''2002:''' In February, former PBS Chief Operating Officer Robert G. Ottenhoff<ref>{{cite web|last=& Karen Everhart Bedford|first=Steve Behrens|title=Rumors rampant as Ottenhoff steps down|url=http://www.current.org/pbs/pbs911o.html|work=Current Online|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref> took on Schmidt's role as president, and Schmidt became Chairman of GuideStar's board.<ref>{{cite web|last=McNamara|first=Don|title=Competition from gov't, funding shut GuideStar U.K.|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/252002602.html|work=The NonProfit Times|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref> At the end of the year, GuideStar released the results of its first annual nonprofit economic survey.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stark|first=Betsy|title=Charities Donations Down|newspaper=ABC World News Tonight with Peter Jennings|date=December 23, 2001}}</ref> *'''2003:''' As part of the May launch of "Operation Phoney Philanthropy", the U.S. [[Federal Trade Commission]] encouraged donors to research charities’ legitimacy on GuideStar before giving.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mack|first=Brenda|title=FTC and States Unite to Fight Fundraising Fraud|url=http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2003/05/opp.shtm|work=Federal Trade Commission|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> That October, GuideStar received a [[U.S. Department of Commerce]] Technology Opportunities Program grant to create a system through which state charity regulators could share information.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wallace|first=Nicole|title=Federal Program Awards $13.95-Million|url=http://philanthropy.com/article/Federal-Program-Awards/62457/|work=Chronicle of Philanthropy|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2004:''' [[California Attorney General]]'s Office modified its Charities Search to one based on a customized version of the GuideStar database and search engine.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wallack|first=Todd|title=Checking on charities to become easier / State attorney general's office signs contract to update Web site|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2004-07-02/business/17433847_1_guidestar-tax-forms-charities|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=September 29, 2011|date=June 24, 2011}}</ref> *'''2005:''' In March 2005, the Interim Report of the Panel of the Nonprofit Sector delivered to the [[Senate Finance Committee]] cited GuideStar’s contributions to nonprofit transparency.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sector|first=Independent|title=Panel on the Nonprofit Sector|url=http://www.nonprofitpanel.org/about/interim/PanelReport.pdf|work=Independent Sector Interim Report|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> In June, GuideStar launched a new Web site that included all tax-exempt organizations registered with the IRS, expanding the database by more than 340,000 nonprofits.<ref>{{cite news|last=Newton|first=Benita|title=Updated site gives users more info on nonprofits|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10AC6511C4DE332E&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=The Virginian-Pilot|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2006:''' GuideStar modified its search engine to make it easier for users to find data.<ref>{{cite web|last=Editors|first=GuideStar|title=Just in Time for the Giving Season, GuideStar Launches Improved Search|url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-6008766/Just-in-Time-for-the.html|work=Business Wire|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2007:''' GuideStar added online donation capabilities to its site; long-time partner [[Network for Good]] processed the donations.<ref>{{cite web|last=nonprofitorgs|title=What Your Nonprofit Needs to Know About GuideStar, Network for Good and Social Media Fundraising|url=http://nonprofitorgs.wordpress.com/2010/01/20/what-your-nonprofit-needs-to-know-about-guidestar-network-for-good-and-social-media-fundraising/|work=Nonprofit Tech 2.0|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> To further connect nonprofits with current and potential supporters, GuideStar launched a beta version of the GuideStar Exchange.<ref>{{cite web|last=Staff|first=Join Together|title=Get Listed on the GuideStar Exchange|url=http://www.drugfree.org/join-together/funding/get-listed-on-the-guidestar|work=The Partnership at Drugfree.org|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2008:''' GuideStar released a new report on characteristics that drive foundation spending patterns.<ref>{{cite web|last=Authors|first=Multiple|title=What Drives Foundation Expenses|url=http://www.urban.org/UploadedPDF/411614_Foundation_Expenses.pdf|work=Urban Institute Report|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2009:''' GuideStar partnered with GreatNonprofits to add stakeholder reviews to organizations' profiles for individuals to communicate their experiences with nonprofits.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ogden|first=Tim|title=The Worst (and Best) Way to Pick A Charity This Year|url=http://www.jackmillercenter.org/tag/guidestar/|work=The Jack Miller Center|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> GuideStar also launched CEO Compensation Checkpoint to analyze nonprofit CEO compensation..<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Pete|title=Checking out Checkpoint|url=http://www.nonprofitmusings.com/2009/08/checking-out-checkpoint.html|work=Nonprofit Musings|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2010:''' GuideStar launched "Take Action@GuideStar" to give donors an easier way to get more information about the causes they were interested in and to provide expert analysis of individual nonprofits working in specific cause areas.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vitanov|first=Deyan|title=Announcing TakeAction@GuideStar!|url=http://www.myphilanthropedia.org/blog/2010/04/01/announcing-takeactionguidestar/|work=Philanthropedia Blog|accessdate=September 29, 2011}}</ref> *'''2011:''' In April, GuideStar acquired [[Philanthropedia]] and Social Actions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two new acquisitions extend GuideStar’s reach|url=http://www.alliancemagazine.org/node/3679|work=Alliance Magazine|accessdate=October 6, 2011}}</ref> In May, GuideStar, in partnership with [[BBB Wise Giving Alliance]] and [[Independent Sector]], launched "Charting Impact"<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Hewlett Foundation|title=Helping Nonprofit Organizations Explore Their Goals and Progress|url=http://www.hewlett.org/newsroom/newsletter/charting-impact|work=Hewlett Foundation Newsroom|accessdate=October 6, 2011}}</ref> to provide a common platform for nonprofits to discuss their impact and results, and share that information publicly.In June, GuideStar launched a new way to buy nonprofit data: GuideStar Premium Pay As You Go, allowing users to purchase a single report for a specific nonprofit featuring GuideStar Premium's data.<ref>{{cite web|last=Joy|first=Kyla|title=How to spot a fake: Nonprofits you don’t want to give to|url=http://www.kylajoyful.com/2011/06/how-to-spot-a-fake-nonprofits-you-dont-want-to-give-to/|work=Kyla Joyful|accessdate=October 20, 2011}}</ref> *'''2012:''' GuideStar and Nonprofit Finance Fund (NFF) launched Financial SCAN (Situation and Comparables Analysis), an online tool to assess a nonprofit's financial health. Financial SCAN can be used as a regular part of nonprofit due diligence and to help understand organizational financial change over time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bernholz|first=Lucy|title=Philanthropy 2173|url=http://philanthropy.blogspot.com/2012/04/putting-data-in-context.html|work=Putting Data in Context|accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref> In July, GuideStar announced that Jacob Harold of the [[William and Flora Hewlett Foundation]] had been selected to replace Bob Ottenhoff as GuideStar's President and CEO, marking the end of Ottenhoff's 10-year tenure at GuideStar. Harold officially assumed his role in October.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jacob Harold Selected To Head GuideStar |date= July 19, 2012|url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/article/detail/jacob-harold-selected-to-head-guidestar-4760|publisher=The NonProfit Times|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref> In October, GuideStar released More Money for More Good, a nonprofit fundraising guidebook, in partnership with Hope Consulting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Reiss|first=Norman|title=Attracting New Donors to Support Your Nonprofit|url=http://www.nonprofitbridge.com/2012/10/attracting-new-donors-to-support-your-nonprofit/|publisher=Nonprofit Bridge|accessdate=November 16, 2012}}</ref> *'''2013:''' In June, GuideStar announced major changes to the GuideStar Exchange, the only program of its kind that encouraged nonprofit transparency on a national scale and allowed nonprofits to supplement the public information that is available from the IRS.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Avery|first1=Sarah|title=The Next Level of Transparency: GuideStar Exchange|url=http://www.friedmanllp.com/article_continue.php?articalID=459|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> The new GuideStar Exchange featured bronze, silver, and gold participation levels based on the amount of information they share with the public via GuideStar.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cunniffe|first1=Eileen|title=GuideStar to Collect Nonprofit Governance Information in League with BoardSource|url=https://nonprofitquarterly.org/governancevoice/23831-guidestar-to-collect-nonprofit-governance-information-in-league-with-boardsource.html|website=Nonprofit Quarterly|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> The changes were made to align more closely with research conducted by Hope Consulting that revealed donors, institutional funders, and financial advisors most want to know basic, financial and impact and effectiveness information about nonprofits.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ulrich|first1=Greg|title=But… Do Donors Want More Data on Nonprofits?|url=http://www.marketsforgood.org/but-do-donors-want-more-data-on-nonprofits/|website=Markets for Good|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> Additionally, GuideStar partnered with Grassroots.org to offer new benefits to nonprofits that participated in the GuideStar Exchange.<ref>{{cite web|title=GuideStar Webinar - Grassroots.org Free Technology Tools and Services|url=http://www.grassroots.org/news/200-guidestar-webinar-grassroots-org-free-technology-tools-and-services|website=Grassroots.org|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> Also in June, GuideStar partnered with Charity Navigator and BBB Wise Giving Alliance to launch the Overhead Myth Campaign.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brandt|first1=Julie|title=Overhead Costs: The Obsession Must Stop|url=http://www.ssireview.org/blog/entry/overhead_costs_the_obsession_must_stop|website=Stanford Social Innovation Review|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> In September 2013, GuideStar and the Foundation Center announced a strategic partnership to deliver much-needed data and resources to the social sector.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cohen|first1=Rick|title=The "Medium Data" Alliance between Guidestar and the Foundation Center: Get Your Information Here!|url=https://nonprofitquarterly.org/management/23124-the-medium-data-alliance-between-guidestar-and-the-foundation-center-get-your-information-here.html|website=Nonprofit Quarterly|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> In November 2013, GuideStar and the Technology Affinity Group (TAG) announced Simplify, a new approach to information sharing between funders and grantees, to ensure more efficiency in the grantmaking process.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lopez|first1=Marisa|title=Introducing Simplify: Streamlining Grant Applications |url=http://www.exponentpartners.com/introducing-simplify-streamlining-grant-applications|website=exponent partners|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> Also in November, GuideStar and Nonprofit Finance Fund (NFF) launched version 2.0 of Financial SCAN. Updates to Financial SCAN include: Expanded peer comparison capabilities, Excel download feature, new pricing, and a longer nonprofit express pass.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kramer|first1=Peter|title=Financial SCAN 2.0! Coming Nov 19|url=http://nonprofitfinancefund.org/blog?keys=Financial+SCAN+2.0|website=Nonprofit Finance Fund|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> *'''2014:''' On Monday, February 24, 2014, GuideStar hosted its first Impact Call, to expand the definition of nonprofit transparency and provide results in a timely and inclusive manner.<ref>{{cite web|title=GuideStar Hosts the First Impact Call|url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1113069169/guidestar-hosts-the-first-impact-call/|website=redOrbit|accessdate=May 14, 2015}}</ref> In June, GuideStar released its new strategic plan, ''GuideStar 2020: Building the Scaffolding of Social Change.''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://philanthropy.com/article/Gates-Foundation-Pledges/152277|title=Gates Foundation Pledges $3-Million to GuideStar to Enhance Nonprofit Database|work=The Chronicle of Philanthropy}}</ref> In October, in partnership with the D5 Coalition and Green 2.0, GuideStar released a tool for nonprofits to compile demographic data on their board members, employees and volunteers, including optional information input on gender, race and ethnicity, sexual orientation, and disability to share for public distribution.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://philanthropy.com/article/GuideStar-Unveils-Online-Tool/152433|title=GuideStar Unveils Online Tool to Gauge Nonprofits’ Diversity|work=The Chronicle of Philanthropy}}</ref> In November, GuideStar announced its goal to raise $10 million in transformational capital between 2014 and 2016 to help expand three essential functions: data innovation, collection, and distribution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tallahassee.com/story/money/2014/11/16/notes-nonprofits-compelling-stories-attract-people-cause/19126105/|title=Notes on nonprofits: Compelling stories attract people to your cause|date=November 16, 2014|work=Tallahassee Democrat}}</ref> The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation committed to a $3 million grant structured as general operating support over three years to align with the strategic plan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/news-articles/3-million-gates-guidestar/|title=$3 Million From Gates To GuideStar|work=The NonProfit Times}}</ref> *'''2016:''' In January, GuideStar upgraded GuideStar Nonprofit Profiles to allow users to more easily identify an organization’s geographic reach, results, sources of funding, financial stability, and leadership.<ref>O'Neil, Megan. "GuideStar Redesigns Charity Profiles to Emphasize Results." The Chronicle of Philanthropy. N.p., January 20, 2016. Web. April 5, 2017. https://www.philanthropy.com/article/GuideStar-Redesigns-Charity/234989 </ref> The redesign shifted emphasis from charity overhead costs to programs and results, a reflection of a broader debate in the nonprofit world about measuring and communicating impact. <ref>O'Neil, Megan. "GuideStar Redesigns Charity Profiles to Emphasize Results." The Chronicle of Philanthropy. N.p., January 20, 2016. Web. April 5, 2017. https://www.philanthropy.com/article/GuideStar-Redesigns-Charity/234989 </ref> In November, GuideStar’s position as a leading source of nonprofit information was reinforced when the Washington Post reported that the Trump Foundation had admitted to self-dealing after a 2015 IRS tax filing was uploaded to GuideStar’s website by the Trump Foundation’s law firm.<ref>Fahrenthold, David A. "Trump Foundation Admits to Violating Ban on 'self-dealing,' New Filing to IRS Shows." The Washington Post. WP Company, November 22, 2016. Web. April 5, 2017. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-foundation-apparently-admits-to-violating-ban-on-self-dealing-new-filing-to-irs-shows/2016/11/22/893f6508-b0a9-11e6-8616-52b15787add0_story.html</ref> *'''2017:''' In June, GuideStar entered into a partnership with the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] to flag SPLC-identified "hate groups" on their web site. Critics of the SPLC objected to this measure as a highly political move. William Boykin, chair of the [[Family Research Council]], one such group which was flagged, said that "at this point, they are becoming an arm of the ultra-left." <ref>{{cite web|title=Nonprofit Tracker Smears Dozens of Conservative Organizations as ‘Hate Groups’ |url= http://dailysignal.com/2017/06/21/nonprofit-tracker-smears-dozens-of-conservative-organizations-as-hate-groups/ |accessdate= June 22, 2017}}</ref> GuideStar then announced it was removing the labels for the time being.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hogan|first1=Susan|title=After conservative backlash, charity tracker GuideStar removes ‘hate group’ labels|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/06/26/after-conservative-backlash-charity-tracker-guidestar-removes-hate-group-labels/|accessdate=July 20, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 26, 2017}}</ref> On June 28, a defamation lawsuit was filed against Guidestar in the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia|Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia]].<ref>LIBERTY COUNSEL, INC. v GUIDESTAR USA, INC.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lc.org/newsroom/details/062817-liberty-counsel-sues-guidestar-over-false-hate-group-label|title=Liberty Counsel Sues GuideStar Over False “Hate Group” Label - Liberty|website=www.lc.org|language=en-US|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>
== Criticism == A charity watch investigator compared [[Charity Navigator]], [[CharityWatch|Charity Watch]], [[Better Business Bureau]], [[Combined Federal Campaign]] and [[GreatNonprofits|Great Nonprofits]]. The investigator praised GuideStar for offering "information rather than making judgments."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.blueavocado.org/content/charity-raters-part-i-charting-bad-and-bad|title=Charity Raters Part I: Charting the Bad and the Bad {{!}} Blue Avocado|website=www.blueavocado.org|language=en|access-date=August 11, 2017}}</ref> After GuideStar placed a notice on the pages of some charities that were listed on the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) "hate list," one of the groups sued GuideStar for defamation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dailysignal.com/2017/06/29/conservative-organization-suing-nonprofit-tracker-regarding-hate-group-labels-on-conservative-groups/|title=Defender of Religious Freedom Sues Nonprofit Tracker GuideStar Over ‘Hate Group’ Labels|last=2017|date=June 29, 2017|website=The Daily Signal|access-date=August 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lc.org/newsroom/details/062817-liberty-counsel-sues-guidestar-over-false-hate-group-label|title=Liberty Counsel Sues GuideStar Over False “Hate Group” Label - Liberty|website=www.lc.org|language=en-US|access-date=August 11, 2017}}</ref> Other charities echoed criticism of GuideStar's use of SPLC's list.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jul/16/alliance-defending-freedom-blasts-defamatory-south/|title=Alliance Defending Freedom blasts ‘defamatory’ Southern Poverty Law Center ‘hate group’ label|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|work=The Washington Times|access-date=August 11, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Awards & Recognition== *In January 1998, GuideStar received an award for Nonprofit Web Site Excellence from ''[[Philanthropy Journal]]'', with an honorable mention for "Service to the Sector" for its searchable database of (at that time) more than 620,000 U.S. nonprofit organizations.<ref>{{cite web|last=White|first=Daphne|title=Cyberspace Fundraising|url=http://www.foundationnews.org/CME/articles.cfm?ID=25&IssueID=1453|work=Foundation News & Commentary|accessdate=October 6, 2011}}</ref> *In December 1999, ''[[NonProfit Times]]'' named GuideStar founder Buzz Schmidt nonprofit executive of the year.<ref>GuideStar. "Arthur "Buzz" Schmidt Named Nonprofit Executive of the Year." GuideStar Blog. N.p., December 1, 1999. Web. April 5, 2017. https://trust.guidestar.org/arthur-buzz-schmidt-named-nonprofit-executive-of-the-year</ref> *In November 2001, [[TIME]] named Schmidt one of seven innovators in philanthropy for the new millennium.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rawe|first=Julie|title=Where Does Your Gift Go?|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,181602,00.html|work=TIME Magazine|accessdate=July 27, 2011|date=October 28, 2001}}</ref> At the end of the year, the [[New Mexico Attorney General’s Office]] launched an on-line Charities Research Service based on a customized version of the GuideStar database and search engine.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schwinn|first=Elizabeth|title=New Mexico to Put Charity Data Online|url=http://philanthropy.com/article/New-Mexico-to-Put-Charity-Data/52325/|work=The Chronicle of Philanthropy|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref> *In August 2000, 2001, and 2002, ''[[NonProfit Times]]'' named GuideStar founder and board chair Buzz Schmidt to the NPT Power and Influence Top 50.<ref>{{cite web|last=Editors|title=On The Move|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/2002-09-30/business/0209300087_1_savannah-college-newport-hampton-university/2|work=Daily Press|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref> *In 2004, GuideStar won the InfoCommerce Model of Excellence Award for distinction in database information publishing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Editors|first=InfoCommerce|title=2004 Award Winners|url=http://www.infocommercegroup.com/industry_research/2004mofe.htm|work=InfoCommerce|accessdate=October 6, 2011}}</ref> *In 2012, founder and board chair Buzz Schmidt and board member Virginia Hodgkinson were recognized by ''[[NonProfit Times]]'' as two of the Top 25 individuals who have shaped the charitable sector in the last 25 years.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Best & The Brightest, Mostly|url=http://highimpactphilanthropy.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/npt-best-and-brightest.pdf|publisher=The NonProfit Times|accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> *On January 31, 2014, GuideStar chief financial officer James Lum received the 2014 Nonprofit CFO Transformational Leader Award at the 2014 Nonprofit CFO of the Year Awards Luncheon.<ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Voices: An interview with GuideStar CFO James Lum, a 2014 Transformational Leader|url=http://www.associationtrends.com/news/finance/commentary/executive-voices-an-interview-with-guidestar-cfo-james-lum-a-2014-transforma|website=Association Trends|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> *In August 2014, 2015, and 2016, GuideStar President and CEO Jacob Harold was named to the NPT Power and Influence Top 50.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clolery|first1=Paul|title=Power and Influence Top 50: Honorees Insist On A Civil Society and Chart A Path Toward It|url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/8-1-14_Top50PI.pdf|website=The NonProfit Times|accessdate=August 7, 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.guidestar.org/}} ** [http://www.guidestar.org/rxg/help/irs-subsection-codes.aspx IRS Subsection Codes] for [[Tax-exempt organization]]s * [http://nccsweb.urban.org/communityplatform/nccs/organization/profile/id/541774039/popup/1 GuideStar] at [[National Center for Charitable Statistics]] ([[Urban Institute]]) * {{Dmoz|Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources/Research_on_Nonprofits/}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = <!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | native_name = حسن علي بن علي | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people - supply only the year unless the exact date is already widely published, as per WP:DOB. For people that have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Qatari]] | other_names = | occupation = Chairman of the [[Hassan Ali Bin Ali Establishment]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}'''Hassan Ali Bin Ali''' ([[Arabic]]: حسن علي بن علي) is a [[Qatari]] businessman and philanthropist. He is the Chairman of the Hassan Ali Bin Ali Establishment, and a leading member of bodies dedicated to sports and disability.
== Business career == Hassan Ali Bin Ali was educated in the [[United Kingdom]] and in [[Lebanon]], and gained his initial business experience working in the Ali Bin Ali Establishment, a family owned business, and served as the Managing Director of Nasser Bin Khalid & Ali Bin Ali Trading & Contracting Company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chairman profile|url=http://www.dohadrugstore.com/Pages.aspx?id=16|publisher=Doha Drug Store|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017234327/http://www.dohadrugstore.com/Pages.aspx?id=16|archivedate=2013-10-17|df=}}</ref>
He is the Chairman of the Hassan Ali Bin Ali Establishment, which comprises [[Doha]] Drug Store, HABA Ready Mix, HABA Lighting, Reliant Electrical & Mechanical, Intramas and a retail division with exclusive boutiques for various European luxury brands.
==Sporting and philanthropic roles== Bin Ali was previously the Vice Chairman of Qatar Tennis & Squash Federation and the Vice Chairman of Qatari Disabled Club. He is currently the Chairman of the [[Shafallah Center|Shafallah Center for Children with Special Needs]].<ref>[http://www.menaeconomicforum.com/mef2/portfolio/hassan-ali-bin-ali/ "Hassan Ali Bin Ali"], ''MENA Economic Forum''. Accessed 06 July 2015.</ref>
Bin Ali is a member of the Honorary Board of the [[International Paralympic Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Honorary Board|url=http://www.paralympic.org/TheIPC/HWA/HonoraryBoard|publisher=IPC}}</ref>
He served as Chairman of the [[Doha 2016 Olympic Bid]] Committee.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/cgi-bin/news/viewnews.cgi?category=1&id=1192808957 Tokyo 2016, Doha 2016 Respond To IOC Seminar]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bin Ali, Hassan Ali}} [[Category:Qatari businesspeople]] [[Category:Qatari philanthropists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} The establishment of the '''Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency''' (IBRA) ({{lang-id|'''Badan Penyehatan Perbankan Nasional'''}} (BPPN)) in early 1998 was one of a series of steps taken by the [[Indonesian government]], in agreement with the [[International Monetary Fund]] on 15 January 1998, in response to the banking and economic crisis which emerged following the onset of the [[Asian monetary crisis]] in mid-1997.<ref>IMF, [https://www.imf.org/external/np/sec/nb/1998/nb9802.htm Statement by the Managing Director on the IMF Program with Indonesia'], 15 January 1998.</ref> Among other things, the drastic depreciation of the [[rupiah]] (Rp) reduced bank [[liquidity]], and loss of public confidence in the rupiah and the banking system in general.
In establishing IBRA, the Indonesian authorities were effectively establishing a "[[Bad bank#Indonesia (1998)|bad bank]]" financial vehicle to allow the segregation of bad debts away from established banks with the aim of promoting the overall recovery of Indonesia's financial system.<ref>Details of the process of bank restructuring following the Asian financial crisis in Indonesia are in Yuri Sato, '[http://www.ide.go.jp/English/Publish/Periodicals/De/pdf/05_01_05.pdf Bank Restructuring and Financial Institution Reform in Indonesia'], ''The Developing Economies'', XLVIII(1), March 2005, pp. 91-120.</ref>
As a measure to cope with the scarcity of liquidity in the nation's banking system, in late 1997 and early 1998 the central bank ([[Bank Indonesia]]), as a lender of the last resort, provided liquidity assistance loans to banks. In addition, the Government instituted a blanket guarantee program for all bank liabilities, to arrest further erosion of confidence towards the system. This process left the Indonesian banking system holding a large number of bad loans at the end of 1997.
==History==
===Establishment===
IBRA was established on 26 January 1998 (based on the Presidential Decree No 27 year 1998)<ref>[http://dprd.jatimprov.go.id/produkhukum/0ca49-KEPRES_27_1998.pdf Keputusan Presiden Republik Indonesia Nomor 27 Tahun 1998] (Presidential Decree No 27 of 1998).</ref> and was planned to have lifespan of five years in order to undertake its tasks. In the event, IBRA’s liquidation took longer than planned and the Agency was finally terminated on 30 April 2004. According to the decree establishing IBRA (Presidential Decree No. 27 Year 1998), IBRA's objectives were to administer the government's blanket guarantee program, and to supervise, manage and restructure distress banks. These objectives were extended on 27 February 1999 to include managing the government’s assets in performing banks under restructuring status and to optimise the recovery rate of asset disposals of distressed banks. IBRA undertook a comprehensive series of activities consisting of bank liability program, bank restructuring, bank loan restructuring, shareholders settlement, and the recovery of state funds. These were carried out by the major operating units within IBRA (Bank Restructuring, Asset Management Credit, Asset Management Investment, Risk Management, and Support and Administration).
IBRA was supervised by the Ministry of Finance, the Financial Sector Policy Committee (FSPC) and the Oversight Committee. A Financial Sector Policy Committee (FSPC/Komite Kebijakan Sektor Keuangan) was formed on 21 August 1998 whose members included the main economic ministers of Indonesia, and the Independent Review Committee (IRC), which includes representatives from [[International Monetary Fund]]s (IMF), the [[World Bank]] and [[Asian Development Bank]] (ADB).
===Controversy=== During the period of the existence of the Agency, IBRA had a troubled record.<ref>Wayne Arnold, '[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/02/business/indonesian-bank-agency-fading-out.html?pagewanted=all Indonesian Bank Agency Fading Our'], ''International New York Times'', 2 October 2003, and Reiner S., '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2002/12/27/ibra-disappoints-ahead-early-closure-next-year.html IBRA disappoints ahead of early closure next year'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 27 December 2002.</ref> The Agency was criticised for being slow in implementing its tasks of restructuring, for lack of transparency, and for alleged irregulatories.<ref>'[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/1999/11/23/ibra-be-audited-soon-says-bambang.html IBRA to be audited soon, says Bambang'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 23 November 1999.</ref> There was also considerable controversy surrounding its operations, including the salaries of senior staff which were said to be very high.<ref>'[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2004/01/30/ibra-bashing.html IBRA bashing'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 30 January 2004.</ref>
===Leadership===
One main problem for the Agency was that, partly because of period of political instability that Indonesia passed through after the fall of [[Suharto|President Suharto]] in May 1998, there were numerous changes in leadership (of the ''Ketua'' or the Chair) of IBRA. During the six years of IBRA's operations, there were a total of seven heads of the Agency.
'''Heads ("Ketua") of IBRA 1998-2004'''
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! No !! Name !! Start !!Finish!!Months |- | 1 || Bambang Subianto || Jan 1998 || Mar 1998||2 |- | 2 || Iwan Prawiranata || Mar 1998 || 22 Jun 1998||3 |- | 3 || Glenn S. Yusuf || 22 Jun 1998 || 12 Jan 2000 || 19 |- | 4 || Cacuk Sudarijanto || 12 Jan 2000 || 6 Nov 2000||10 |- | 5|| Edwin Gerungan || 6 Nov 2000 || 25 Jun 2001 ||7 |- | 6|| I Putu Gede Ary Suta || 25 Jun 2001 || 19 Apr 2002||10 |- | 7|| Syafruddin Arsjad Temenggung ||19 Apr 2002 || 27 Feb 2004||22 |- |}
===Closure=== When the Agency was finally closed at the end of April 2004,<ref>[http://www.esdm.go.id/prokum/keppres/2004/keppres-15-2004.pdf Presidential Decree No 15 of 2004] formally closing the Agency was signed on 27 February 2004.</ref> the head of Indonesia's Supreme Audit Agency, [[Satrio Budihardjo Joedono|Billy Joedono]] was cautious about reaching conclusions about the performance of IBRA. Before submitting a report to the Indonesian Parliament, Billy Joedono noted that IBRA appeared to have done its job in restructuring the majority of troubled banks but nevertheless left further conclusions about the performance of IBRA to the Parliament.<ref>Tony Hotland, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2004/05/08/ibra-did-job-success-unclear-says-audit-agency.html IBRA did job, but success unclear, says audit agency'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 8 May 2004.</ref>'

revision.text:
The '''Integrated Circuit Topography Act''' ("An Act to provide for the protection of integrated circuit topographies and to amend certain Acts in consequence thereof", C-37) is legislation passed by the [[Parliament of Canada]] in 1990 that regulates the [[intellectual property]] of [[mask work|integrated circuit topographies]]. It came into force in 1993. The Act provides [[exclusive right]]s for the creator of the integrated circuit topography and remedies to deter infringement. The exclusive right is transferable. To receive the exclusive right to an integrated circuit topography the topography must be registered at the [[Canadian Intellectual Property Office]]. Between 1993 and 1999 there were about 38 registrations under the Act.
Integrated Circuit Topographies (ICT) are electronic integrated circuits or '''IC products''' that are configured and interconnected. These creations are protected in Canada by the Integrated Circuit Topography Act, which gives the creator exclusive rights for a period of ten years after registration. Because products containing these circuits are often exported outside Canada, Canada has reciprocal agreements with other countries that also protect the design for ten years.
Sources: Entrepreneurship: Creating a Venture By: Lori Cranson and Madeline Dennis
== External links == * [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/I-14.6/ Integrated Circuit Topography Act (<abbr>S.C.</abbr> 1990, c. 37)] * [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-93-212/index.html Integrated Circuit Topography Regulations (SOR/93-212)] * [http://strategis.ic.gc.ca/sc_mrksv/cipo/welcome/welcom-e.html Report to Canadian Parliament]
[[Category:Canadian federal legislation]] [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:1990 in Canadian law]]

{{infobox company |image = |name = Interogo Foundation |founded = 1989 |area_served = Worldwide |founder = [[Ingvar Kamprad]] |hq_location = [[Liechtenstein]] |brands = |parent = |subsid = [[Inter IKEA Holding S.A.]]
[[Interogo Holding A.G.]] (non-[[IKEA]] related) |website = {{url|https://www.interogoholding.com/governance/interogo-foundation}} |type = [[Private foundation|Foundation]] }} {{Template:IKEA ownership chart}} '''Interogo Foundation''' is a [[Foundation (nonprofit organization)|foundation]] registered in Liechtenstein. It owns [[Inter IKEA Holding S.A.]] registered in Luxembourg, which owns [[Inter IKEA Systems B.V.]], registered in the Netherlands, and thereby controls the [[intellectual property]] of the [[IKEA]] brand. [[Ingvar Kamprad]], the founder of IKEA, and his family control the Interogo Foundation.{{Cite news|url=http://www.svt.se/ug/ingvar-kamprad-bekraftar-stiftelsen-i-mejl-till-tt |title=Ingvar Kamprad bekräftar stiftelsen i mejl till TT |publisher=Svt.se |date= 2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-28|language=swedish}} Royalties of 3% on all IKEA products has resulted in the foundation controlling assets valued at US $15 billion.{{Cite news|url=http://www.svt.se/ug/ingvar-kamprad-gommer-ikea-miljarder-i-skatteparadis |title=Kamprad gömmer Ikea-miljarderna i skatteparadis |publisher=Svt.se |date= 2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-28|language=swedish}} ==History == The foundation was founded on the 29 March 1989 in Vaduz, Liechtenstein. The aim of the foundation is to secure the continued existence of Inter IKEA Holding S.A. and to influence the leadership of the company.{{Cite web|url=http://svt.se/content/1/c8/02/30/50/85/Stadgar_Interogo.pdf |title=Gruendungsurkunde |publisher=Interogo Foundations |date= 1989-03-29|accessdate=2011-01-28|language=german|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009000003/http://www.svt.se/content/1/c8/02/30/50/85/Stadgar_Interogo.pdf|archive-date=October 9, 2012}} ==Governance== The foundation board has at least two members, who were originally lawyers Herbert Oberhuber and Johannes Burger. The foundation may be changed into a company or a trust if circumstances have changed so that this is in the foundation's interests. Meetings of the board are announced by the president of the foundation. === Appo Trust === The members of Interogo Foundation can be appointed or replaced by the Appo Trust based in [[Ontario]], [[Canada]], or by an equal trust created by the Interogo Foundation. Appo Trust is currently controlled by the [[Kamprad]] family. {{Cite news|url=http://www.smp.se/inblick/two-people-in-total-control/|title=Two people in total control - Smålandsposten|last=Vikingson|first=Bosse|work=Smålandsposten|access-date=2018-11-18|language=sv-SE}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.va.se/nyheter/2011/01/27/kamprads-20-miljardersklipp/|title=Kamprads 20-miljardersklipp|work=Veckans affärer|access-date=2018-11-18}} ==See also== * [[IKEA]] * [[Stichting INGKA Foundation]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121009000003/http://www.svt.se/content/1/c8/02/30/50/85/Stadgar_Interogo.pdf Founding document of the foundation.] * [http://www.svt.se/ug/granskningen-av-ikea-ett-brett-samarbetsprojekt Information from the Nation Swedish Broadcasting Company, SVT.] {{sv}} {{IKEA ownership}} {{business-org-stub}} [[Category:Companies of Liechtenstein]] [[Category:1989 establishments in Liechtenstein]] [[Category:IKEA]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Kenneth E. Brailsford | image = Kenneth E Brailsford.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Niagara Falls, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Park City, Utah]] | nationality = American | alma_mater = | occupation = Founder & CEO of Zija International | years_active = | home_town = | spouse = Linda Hughes Brailsford | children = | website = {{URL|http://kenbrailsford.com/}} }} '''Kenneth E. Brailsford''' is an American entrepreneur, investor and philanthropist.{{cite news|last1=Allred|first1=Cathy|title=KEB wins Lehi Roller Mills bid, court approves sale|url=http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/north/lehi/keb-wins-lehi-roller-mills-bid-court-approves-sale/article_21115678-cd71-54f8-b1fb-b76b46e0659c.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Daily Herald|date=Aug 21, 2013}} He is known as a pioneer in the nutritional supplement and network marketing industry and considered the “Father of Herbal Encapsulation”.{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurship Lecture Series|url=https://www.uvu.edu/entrepreneurship/resources/lectures/fall-2015.html|website=Entrepreneurship Institute|accessdate=25 August 2017}} Brailsford was the first to commercially introduce herbs in capsule form when he co-founded [[Nature's Sunshine Products|Nature’s Sunshine]] in 1972.{{cite news|title=Industry Veteran Ken Brailsford, Founder of Zija, Pens Autobiography|url=http://directsellingnews.com/index.php/view/industry_veteran_ken_brailsford_founder_of_zija_pens_autobiography#.WaBfkYqQxBy|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Direct Selling News|date=November 12, 2015}} He later went on to found two more network marketing companies—Enrich International in 1985{{cite web|title=Enrich International, Inc. History|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/enrich-international-inc-history/|website=Funding Universe|accessdate=25 August 2017}} and Zija International in 2006, both of which are still in operation.{{cite news|title=Zija International Acquires XANGO|url=http://directsellingnews.com/index.php/view/zija_international_acquires_xango#.WaBj4YqQxBw|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Direct Selling News|date=May 10, 2017}} == Early life and education == Brailsford was born in 1944 in [[Niagara Falls, New York]], to Robert Earl and Freeda Webster Brailsford.{{cite news|title=Mission Presidents|url=http://www.ldschurchnewsarchive.com/articles/41151/Mission-presidents.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=LDS Church News Archive|date=January 12, 2002}} He served in the [[United States Army|US Army]] for two years after graduating from [[Brigham Young University]] with a degree in [[economics]] in 1969.{{cite web|last1=Nuyten|first1=Ted|title=Ken Brailsford – Founder Zija International Interview|url=https://www.businessforhome.org/2015/08/ken-brailsford-founder-zija-international-interview/|website=Business For Home|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Career == Brailsford co-founded [[Nature's Sunshine Products|Nature’s Sunshine]] in 1972 and served as President of the company from 1972-1979. After leaving Nature’s Sunshine, he went to work as a stockbroker for a short time, but then reemerged in the herbal industry once his non-compete agreement with Nature’s Sunshine had expired. Brailsford then went on to help launch Nature’s Labs Inc., later renamed Enrich International. He worked there from 1985-1997 and retired in 1997.{{cite news|title=Zija Founder Kenneth Brailsford Receives Outstanding Alumni Award|url=http://directsellingnews.com/index.php/view/zija_founder_kenneth_brailsford_receives_outstanding_alumni_award#.WaBsuoqQxBx|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Direct Selling News|date=September 29, 2015}} In 2004, his interest in [[Pharmacology|pharmacology]] led him to the [[Moringa oleifera|Moringa oleifera]] plant—a superfood prized for its high levels of vitamins, minerals, vital proteins, antioxidants and omega oils. In 2006, he founded Zija International to bring the benefits of Moringa to market. Brailsford has over 35 years in the [[Direct selling|Direct Sales]] industry. Brailsford owns a [[Private equity firm|private equity firm]], KEB Enterprises L.P., that manages other business [[Investment|investments]].{{cite web|title=About KEB Enterprises|url=http://www.kebenterprises.com/about/|website=KEB Enterprises|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Awards == [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of the Year]] (1994){{cite news|title=Orem Man Receives Entrepreneur Award|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/366516/OREM-MAN-RECEIVES-ENTREPRENEUR-AWARD.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Deseret News|date=July 26, 1994}}
[[Utah Valley University|UVU]] Outstanding Alumni Award (2015)
Utah’s #1 Fastest-Growing Company Zija International (2014){{cite web|last1=Dunkley|first1=Nicole|title=Zija, CEO, Rodney Larsen Zija International Awarded As Utah’s #1 Growing Company|url=https://www.businessforhome.org/2014/09/zija-international-awarded-as-utahs-1-growing-company/|website=Business For Home|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Personal Life == Ken married his college sweetheart, Linda Hughes Brailsford, and they are the parents of six children, twenty-four grandchildren, and seven great grandchildren. He and his wife currently live in [[Park City, Utah]].{{cite web|last1=Dunkley|first1=Nicole|title=Network Marketing Icon Ken Brailsford Pens Autobiography|url=https://www.businessforhome.org/2015/10/zija-internationals-ken-brailsford-pens-autobiography/|website=Business For Home|accessdate=25 August 2017}} Brailsford is a member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints]], sometimes nicknamed the Mormon or LDS Church. Among other assignments, Brailsford has served as a [[Bishop (Latter Day Saints)|bishop]], stake clerk, counselor in a [[Stake (Latter Day Saints)|stake presidency]], and from 2005 to 2008 as [[Mission president|president]] of the church’s Columbus [[South Carolina]] [[Mission (LDS Church)|mission]].{{cite news|title=New Mission Presidents|url=http://www.ldschurchnewsarchive.com/articles/47044/New-mission-presidents.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=LDS Church News|date=March 26, 2005}} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brailsford, Kenneth E.}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
A '''[[social entrepreneurship|social entrepreneur]]''' is an [[entrepreneur]] who works to increase [[social capital]] by founding [[social venture]]s, including charities, for-profit businesses with social causes, and other non-government organizations. These types of activities are distinct from work of non-operating foundations and philanthropists who provide funding and other support for them.
==Notable historical social entrepreneurs== * [[Qais Al Khonji]] ([[Oman]]) - Founder of Genesis projects and investments * [[Vinoba Bhave]] ([[India]]) – Founder and leader of the [[Bhoodan movement]], he caused the redistribution of more than 7,000,000 acres (28,000 km²) of land to aid India's [[Dalit|untouchables]] and landless. [[Mahatma Gandhi]] described him as his mentor. * [[David Brower]] ([[United States]]) — Environmentalist and conservationist, he served as the Sierra Club's first executive director and built it into a worldwide network for environmental issues. He also founded [[Friends of the Earth]], the [[League of Conservation Voters]] and The [[Earth Island Institute]]. * [[Akhtar Hameed Khan]] ([[Pakistan]]) — Founder of grassroots movement for rural communities [[Comilla Model]], and low-cost [[sanitation]] programmes ([[Orangi Pilot Project]]) for squatter settlements. * [[Maria Montessori]] ([[Italy]]) — Developed the Montessori approach to early childhood education. * [[John Muir]] ([[United States]]) — Naturalist and conservationist, he established the [[National Park System]] and helped found The Sierra Club. * [[Florence Nightingale]] ([[United Kingdom]]) — Founder of modern nursing, she established the first school for nurses and fought to improve hospital conditions. * [[Frederick Law Olmsted]] ([[United States]]) — Creator of major urban parks, including [[Rock Creek Park]] in Washington DC, [[Central Park]] in NYC, and [[Mount Royal Park]] in Montreal, he is generally considered to have developed the profession of [[landscape architecture]] in America. * [[Gifford Pinchot]] ([[United States]]) — Champion of the forest as a multiple use environment, [[Gifford Pinchot]] helped found the [[Yale School of Forestry]] and created the U.S. [[United States Forest Service|Forest Service]], serving as its first chief. * [[Friedrich Wilhelm Raiffeisen]] ([[Germany]]) — Pioneer of the rural [[bond of association]] as a substitute for collateral in [[microfinance]], and a principal founder of the [[History of credit unions|credit union]] and [[cooperative banking|cooperative bank]] sectors that now form a major segment of the European banking system. * Dr [[Verghese Kurien]] ([[India]]) — father of the India’s milk revolution. It was Kurien’s foresight, planning and execution, India through the ‘white revolution’, went from a milk importing country to the world’s largest producer. In a career spanning close to 60 years, Kurien founded around 30 institutions of excellence like Gujarat Co-operative Milk Marketing Federation (GCMMF), Institute of Rural Management, Anand (IRMA) and The National Dairy Development Board’s (NDDB). * [[Margaret Sanger]] ([[United States]]) — Founder of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, she led the movement for family planning efforts around the world. * [[John Woolman]] ([[United States]]) — He Led U.S. Quakers to voluntarily emancipate all their slaves between 1758 and 1800, his work also influenced the British [[Society of Friends]], a major force behind the British decision to ban slaveholding. Quakers, of course, became a major force in the U.S. abolitionist movement as well as a key part of the infrastructure of the Underground Railroad. * [[Sam Pitroda]] ([[India]]) – Chairman, National Innovation Council, India * [[Adhik Kadam]] ([[India]]) – Founder Chairman of Borderless World Foundation. He is on peace building mission, working in most conflicted areas in Asia i.e Jammu & Kashmir on India Pakistan Border. He is working for the children who lost parents in terrorism and conflict.

{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox accounting body |image = MIA logo.jpg |image_border = |alt = |image_caption = |abbreviation = MIA |motto = Accountants: Managers of Value |predecessor = <!-- Name of any predecessor entity if any --> |formation = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1967|01|01}} |legal_status = [[Body corporate]] incorporated under the Accountants Act, 1967 of the [[Parliament of Malaysia]] |objective = Regulate and develop the accounting profession in [[Malaysia]] |headquarters = [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia |coords = |region_served = [[Malaysia]] |membership_num = 34947 members (as of 18 July 2018) |students_num = <!-- No of students --> |members_designations = C.A.(M), L.A.(M) or A.M.(M) |language = English and Malay |highest_officer_title = President |highest_officer_name = Salihin Abang |second_officer_title = Vice-President |second_officer_name = Dato' Narendra Kumar Jasani |third_officer_title = Chief Executive Officer |third_officer_name = Dr Nurmazilah Dato' Mahzan ||administering_organ = Council |IFAC_membership_date = 7 October 1977 |additional_data_name1 = |additional_data1 = |additional_data_name2 = |additional_data2 = |additional_data_name3 = |additional_data3 = |num_staff = |website = {{URL|http://www.mia.org.my}} |remarks = }}
'''Malaysian Institute of Accountants''' ('''MIA''') is the umbrella body for the [[accountancy]] profession in [[Malaysia]]. It was established under the Accountants Act, 1967 to regulate and develop the accountancy profession in this country. MIA operates under the purview of the [[Ministry of Finance (Malaysia)|Ministry of Finance]] through the Accountant General's Department.
MIA is the only accountancy body empowered by law to [[regulation|regulate]] the accountancy profession in Malaysia, thus making MIA membership mandatory for those holding themselves out or practising as an [[accountant]] in the country. MIA’s membership encompasses both legal and market recognition for accountants in Malaysia.
Members of MIA are conferred with the designation Chartered Accountant Malaysia, abbreviated as `C.A.(M)’. This designation is given to a professional in accountancy, business and finance with recognised accountancy qualification and relevant work experience. At present, there are more than 34,500 MIA members working in all industries and states of Malaysia.
As an umbrella body for all the accountants in Malaysia, MIA’s responsibilities include education and quality assurance as well as enforcement, to maintain the credibility of the profession and the public interest.<ref>{{cite web|title=About MIA|url=https://www.mia.org.my/v2/discover-mia/discover-mia.aspx|accessdate=18 July 2018}}</ref> MIA is a member of the [[International Federation of Accountants]] (IFAC)<ref>{{cite web|title=Members|url=http://www.ifac.org/about-ifac/membership/members?letter=M|publisher=IFAC|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> and the [[ASEAN Federation of Accountants]] (AFA).<ref>{{cite web|title=Membership|url=http://www.aseanaccountants.org/abo_membership.htm|publisher=AFA|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
MIA hosted the 18th [[World Congress of Accountants]] from 8–11 November 2010, which was held at the [[Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre]]. A record number of 6,000 delegates from 134 countries participated. The Congress, which originated in 1904 and has been held regularly since 1977, was jointly organised by the MIA and the [[International Federation of Accountants]] (IFAC).<ref>[http://www.ifac.org/news-events/2010-11/world-congress-accountants-2010-opens-record-number-delegates World Congress of Accountants 2010 Opens with Record Number of Delegates], IFAC. 8 November 2010. Retrieved 15 January 2014.</ref>
==Presidents of MIA== The President is elected among the members of MIA Council. Among those who served as President are: * Dato' Shamsir Omar (1967–87) * Dato' Hanifah Noordin (1987–99) * Dato' Syed Amin Aljeffri (2000) * Tan Sri Abdul Samad Hj. Alias (2000–05) * Abdul Rahim Abdul Hamid (2005–07) * Nik Mohd Hasyudeen Yusoff (2007–09) * Abdul Rahim Abdul Hamid (2009–11) * Datuk Mohd Nasir Ahmad (2011–13) * Datuk Johan Idris (2013–15) * Dato' Mohammad Faiz Azmi (2015–17) * Salihin Abang (2017–Present)

{{Infobox person | name = Markus Diethelm | image = File:Markus U. Diethelm.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|10|22|df=y}} | nationality = Switzerland | alma_mater = [[University of Zurich]]
[[Stanford University]] }} '''Markus U. Diethelm''' (born 22 October 1957) is a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] businessman. Currently, he serves as Group General Counsel of [[UBS|UBS Group AG]], holding this position since 2014. Prior to that, he held the same position at [[UBS|UBS AG]] since September 2008, when Diethelm was initially appointed as a member of the Group Executive Board of [[UBS]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ubs.com/global/en/about_ubs/corporate-governance/group-executive-board/cv-markus-diethelm.html|title=Markus U. Diethelm CV|publisher=UBS.com|accessdate=2015-11-16}} Additionally, he served as an Executive Board member of UBS Business Solutions AG from 2015 to 2016. ==Education== Diethelm holds a law degree (lic.iur.) from the [[University of Zurich]] and a [[Master's degree]] as well as a [[PhD]] ([[Doctor of Juridical Science|JSD]]) from [[Stanford Law School]].{{cite web|title=Markus U. Diethelm: Executive Profile & Bibliography|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=32758579&privcapId=416620|publisher=Bloomberg Business|accessdate=2015-12-28}} ==Career== Diethelm is a qualified [[attorney-at-law]] and is admitted to the bar in [[Zurich]], [[Geneva]] and [[New York City]]. In 1983, Diethelm started his career with the Zurich law firm Bär & Karrer. He worked at [[Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison]] in [[New York City]] in 1988 as a foreign associate. A year later, he practiced at New York's [[Shearman & Sterling]], specializing in [[mergers and acquisitions]]. In 1992, he joined a [[Los Angeles]] law firm [[Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher]], focusing on corporate matters, securities transactions, litigation and regulatory investigations while operating out of the firm's [[Brussels]] and [[Paris]] offices. He stayed with [[Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher]] until 1998. ===Swiss Re=== On 1 April 1998, Diethelm joined [[Swiss Re]] as Group [[Chief Legal Officer]]{{cite web|title=Bloomberg Profile|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=32758579&ticker=FONC:SW|publisher=bloomberg.com|accessdate=2015-02-09}} and was appointed to the Executive Board with effect from January 1, 2007. Under his leadership, [[Swiss Re]] introduced a successful global model for the Group's legal and compliance organization. Furthermore, Diethelm played a key role in the company's [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] litigation and in major corporate development transactions.{{cite web|url=http://media.swissre.com/documents/pr_20061215_board_en.pdf|title=Swiss Re appoints George Quinn as Chief Financial Officer as of 1 March 2007 - The Executive Board is further reinforced with three additional appointments |publisher=Swiss Re|accessdate=2006-12-15}} ===UBS=== Markus Diethelm became a member of the Group Executive Board and was appointed as Group General Counsel of UBS on 1 September 2008. Following the restructuring process, he was appointed to the same position within the UBS Group AG in 2014. He works closely with Colin Bell, the head of operational risk.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-12-05/ubs-names-koerner-asset-management-head-as-fraser-retires-1- |title=UBS Names Ulrich Koerner to Head Asset Management Unit |publisher=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=2015-01-08}} In 2009, Diethelm negotiated with the U.S Department of Justice Tax Division Attorney [[Kevin M. Downing]] in an investigation about [[tax fraud]]. The UBS paid $780 million and revealed several client names.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/04/09/us-banks-ubs-idUSTRE6380UA20100409 |title=How the U.S. cracked open secret vaults at UBS |publisher=Reuters.com|accessdate=2015-01-08}} ==Other mandates== Markus U. Diethelm holds the following mandates: * Board member of UBS Business Solutions AG * Chairman of the Swiss-American Chamber of Commerce’s legal committee{{cite web|url=http://www.amcham.ch/leadership/p_leadership.asp?id=13|title=Leadership - American Chamber of Commerce Switzerland|publisher=Swiss-American Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=2015-12-28}} * Chairman of the Swiss Advisory Council of the [[American Swiss Foundation]] * Member of the Foundation Council of the UBS International Center of Economics in Society{{cite web|url=https://www.ubscenter.uzh.ch/index.php/en/about/council|title=UBS Center - Economics. For society|publisher=UBS Foundation of Economics in Society|accessdate=2015-12-28}} * Member of the Professional Ethics Commission of the Association of Swiss Corporate Lawyers * Member of the Supervisory Board of the Fonds de Dotation LUMA / Arles * Member of the Foundation Board of the International Red Cross and Red Crecsent Museum{{Cite web|url=https://www.redcrossmuseum.ch/en/the-museum/the-foundation-board/|title=The Foundation Board|last=|first=|date=|website=www.redcrossmuseum.ch|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} ==Publications== * Markus U. Diethelm, Markus U. 2001. "Globalization and the Future of the International Practice of Law from a General Counsel's Perspective of a Multinational Enterprise – A Navigator of Management and Steward of the 'Future of Law'?" In: Drolshammer, J. I. & Pfeifer, M. (eds.). ''The Internationalization of the Practice of Law." Netherlands: [[Kluwer Law International]].'' * Dr. Markus U. Diethelm 217 Group General Counsel, (JBS AG, Zürich) 2016. "Rechtliche Herausforderungen im internationalen Banking" In: Kellerhals, Andreas (Hrsg.): "Herausforderungen für die Schweiz und Europa : Referate zu Fragen der Zukunft Europas 2015" Zürich: Schulthess. * [http://www.fuw.ch/article/gesellschaftliche-verantwortung/ "Gesellschaftliche Verantwortung" in ''Finanz und Wirtschaft'', May 7, 2014] ==References== {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite journal |url=http://www.weltwoche.ch/ausgaben/2017-28/artikel/die-einmann-armee-der-banken-die-weltwoche-ausgabe-282017.html |title=Die Einmann-Armee der Banken |journal=Die Weltwoche |issue=28/2017 }} * {{cite news |url=https://www.finews.ch/news/banken/26671-ubs-frankreich-vergleich-markus-diethelm |title=UBS-Chefjurist Markus Diethelm pokert in Frankreich um Milliarden |work=finews.ch |date=March 20, 2017 }} ==External links== *[https://www.ubs.com/global/en/about_ubs/corporate-governance/group-executive-board/cv-markus-diethelm.html Curriculum vitae on UBS website] *[https://www.ubs.com/global/en/about_ubs/corporate_covernance/group-executive-board.html List of UBS executive board members] {{UBS AG}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Diethelm, Markus U.}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:UBS people]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:Swiss lawyers]] [[Category:University of Zurich alumni]] [[Category:Stanford Law School alumni]] [[Category:Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison people]] [[Category:People associated with Shearman & Sterling]]
